summary: This document is a technical guide from AT&T explaining the structure and interpretation of call detail records (CDRs) and other telecommunication data reports. It provides detailed descriptions of fields, codes, and scenarios for mobility voice, SMS, data, wireline, and international call records. The document appears to be a reference guide for law enforcement or authorized personnel interpreting phone records, likely produced in response to a subpoena or legal request in the Epstein case.
keyFacts: The document is a technical guide from AT&T explaining how to interpret call detail records (CDRs) and other telecommunication data.
It covers multiple report types including mobility voice, SMS, data, wireline, and international call records.
The guide explains technical fields like IMEI, IMSI, cell site location identifiers (LAC/CID, ECGI), and various call features and codes.
It clarifies that blank fields or "-I" do not indicate record issues but mean information wasn't passed from the network to the CDR system.
The document states that AT&T searches all available databases to ensure all responsive records are provided in response to requests.
